Lowering the Boom on Oil Spills

by Dan del Villano


PWGSC employees and contractors learn the serious business of marine spill cleanup at the esquimalt Graving Dock. The orange inflatable boom is used to control oil spills.

In early spring, the Esquimalt Graving Dock, Canada's biggest dry dock, was teh site of oil spill training for PWGSC employees and contractors who work at the facility.

The course covered: the characteristics and safe handling of petroleum products, personal protective equipment, containment, clean up, storage, and waste management. These were explained through case studies, hands-on demonstrations and field exercises.

Daryl Lawes, an Environmental Coordinator at the Graving Dock, stresses that the training isn't in isolation. "This course was a follow up to an earlier course on cleaning up and avoiding land spills," he says. "The training is part of our standing oil spill contingency plan." There hasn't been a marine spill in the two years that Lawes has been working at the Dock, but he isn't planning to take any chances.


Erring on the side of caution, the Esquimalt Graving Dock always has a boom deployed.

Perhaps more importantly, the marine spill response training is another step in getting ISO 14001 certification. ISO 14001 is an internationally recognized environmental management standard and the Esquimalt Graving Dock is the only large shipbuilding/repair facility in the world that will soon be certified.

Bill Pleming is PWGSC's Regional Safety Officer and he travelled from Vancouver to take part in the training. He says that what really impressed him was the cooperation between PWGSC, the Departmetn of National Defence, and the private sector: "It was really proactive all the way around."

Source: Ensemble, August 2000, Volume 8, No. 6
